revision.comment: removed [[Category:German photographers]]; added [[Category:Photographers from Berlin‎]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jim Rakete | image = Jim rakete frankfurt.jpg | image_upright = yes | caption = Jim Rakete, 2008 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|01|01|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] | occupation = photographer, filmmaker and writer. }}
'''Günther "Jim" Rakete''' (German: [[Help:IPA for German|[dʒɪm ʁakeːtə]]]; born 1 January 1951 in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]) is a photographer, photojournalist, filmmaker, writer and producer based in Berlin.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jimrakete.com/en/vita|title=Jim Rakete Fotografie Photography|last=|first=|website=www.jimrakete.com|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref>
Rakete shot numerous personalities from the German and international music and film scene and politics. His managerial work behind the award-winning musical acts [[Nina Hagen Band]], [[Interzone (band)|Interzone]], [[Nena]] and [[Die Ärzte]] made Rakete a decisive figure in the burgeoning [[Neue Deutsche Welle|German New Wave]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.welt.de/regionales/berlin/article1545768/Jim-Rakete-und-die-ungeschminkte-Wahrheit.html|title=Jim Rakete und die ungeschminkte Wahrheit|last=Krampitz|first=Dirk|date=2008-01-12|newspaper=Welt Online|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref>
Rakete had extended living and production periods between Los Angeles and Hamburg until his return to Berlin in 2001, where he continues to work in film, photography, writing, theater, music, and production.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.galeriehilanehvonkories.de/en/rakete/vita.php|title=Galerie Hilaneh von Kories - Thomas Bak: Vita|website=www.galeriehilanehvonkories.de|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref>
== Early life == Rakete spent his childhood in [[West Berlin]]. At four years old he was given his first camera, an Agfa box camera, similar to a [[Brownie (camera)|Brownie]], which accompanied him for years.<ref name=":1" /> Rakete continued photographing throughout his school years; fascinated by the mechanisms of photography, he spent a good part of his youth working in the darkroom. At age seventeen, he began to work as a photojournalist for local dailies, agencies and magazines,<ref name=":0" /> while still delivering newspapers to raise the money to buy his first drum kit. His early band efforts lead him towards his personal pathway into the music world.
As the [[Protests of 1968|student movement]] extended to Germany in the late 60s, Rakete brought his eye and camera to document the people, settings and discussions emerging at the time; he was a photojournalist by day and musicians’ photographer by night. By his early twenties he was working for German newspapers while keeping on shooting album band covers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.n-tv.de/leute/Jim-Rakete-duest-ins-Rentenalter-article16658641.html|title=Deutscher Starfotograf Nummer 1: Jim Rakete düst ins Rentenalter|last=Nachrichtenfernsehen|first=n-tv|website=n-tv.de|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> Between 1975 and 1976 Rakete developed several magazines for [[Bauer Media Group|Bauer Verlag Munich]] while commuting between Munich and Berlin.
== Fabrik Rakete and Music Management == In 1977, Rakete rented a 300 square meter loft in the heart of [[Kreuzberg|Berlin's borough of Kreuzberg]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/1893720-Fabrik-Rakete|title=Fabrik Rakete|website=Discogs|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> ''Fabrik Rakete'', a creative laboratory for music, photography and art, was born.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/kultur/kunst/4672874/Jim-Rakete-und-die-schwierigen-Stars-der-Burg|title=Jim Rakete und die schwierigen Stars der Burg|website=DiePresse.com|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> In the two shooting spaces that were built, Rakete's work became crucial for the advancement of the burgeoning [[Neue Deutsche Welle|German New Wave]].
Through a chance encounter Rakete came across the remarkable voice of a sheer powerful 4-octave miracle: [[Nina Hagen]]. Rakete took her first pictures in the then barren, newly funded ''Fabrik Rakete''. Shortly thereafter, [[CBS]], with which Hagen had already signed a recording deal, appointed Rakete as band manager for the newly formed Nina Hagen Band to focus on the launch of the eponymous album in 1978.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.einfach-nina.de/frame.html|title=Nina Hagen Archiv|website=www.einfach-nina.de|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> Successful performances in the Quartier Latin<ref>{{Citation|last=DocSpliff|title=NINA HAGEN BAND - 1. Live Gig (Quartier Latin, Berlin {{!}} 28.2.1978) and more...|date=2009-09-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=upWjTd0bOSo|accessdate=2016-05-31}}</ref> and airplay on German Radio promoted their debut record, which eventually peaked at number eleven in Germany, while also gathering substantial success in Austria and the Netherlands. [[Nina Hagen Band (album)|''Nina Hagen Band'']] was certified gold in France and it went double platinum in Germany. As Nina unexpectedly quit the project, the band was orphan of its main member just as the demand for appearances exploded, with the band still under the CBS deal. Eventually, Rakete, Hagen and the band agreed to record their second and last album,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Nina Hagen. That's Why the Lady is a Punk|last=Feige|first=Marcel|publisher=Schwarzkopf + Schwarzkopf|year=2002|isbn=3896024132|location=|pages=}}</ref> [[Unbehagen]] (1979). The album went gold in Germany and France, selling over 300.000 copies in Germany alone. Despite Hagen's departure, Rakete consolidated his bond with the band, which eventually went on performing under the name [[Spliff (band)|Spliff]]. The new band (which also included members of rock theater group [[Lokomotive Kreuzberg|Lok Kreuzberg]]) and Rakete embarked on the writing of a small Rock Opera in the form of a radio show,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deutsche-mugge.de/interviews/2008/2044-reinhold-heil.html|title=Reinhold Heil - Deutsche Mugge|website=www.deutsche-mugge.de|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref> using the [[AFN Berlin|AFN]] legend [[:de:Rik De Lisle|Rik Delisle]] as host, Aussie performer [[Alf Klimek|Alf Klimek "Klimax"]] as singer and with the later addition of Dutch singer Josee van Irsel. ''[https://www.discogs.com/Spliff-The-Spliff-Radio-Show/master/95998 The Spliff Radio Show]'' premiered live at Kant-Kino on May 2, 1980.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europopmusic.eu/Germany_pages/Spliff.html|title=Spliff - Europopmusic|website=www.europopmusic.eu|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> Tours ensued, and in 1982 the band released their greatest success, ''[[85555]]'', named after the record's catalogue number. Their following album, ''Herzlichen Glückwunsch!'' was released in the later months of the same year.
In the meantime, Spliff and the Fabrik doubled in size the roster of artists: the studios were slowly transforming into a veritable Rock ‘n’ Roll hot shop, with new releases by [[Interzone (band)|Interzone]] and the [[:de:Edo Zanki|Edo Zanki]] Band. The Fabrik studios ran ceaselessly with Rakete developing campaigns, shooting record covers or posters by day, while musicians and producers sent out banners and press material across Berlin and German media at night.
The Fabrik had long moved to Berlin's [[Oranienplatz]] when the members of Spliff started producing emerging artists. Their first production was the 1983 international chart success ''[[Nena (album)|Nena]]'', [[Nena|Gabriele "Nena" Kerner]]'s first album. An instant hit, the Nena Band toured countless European TVs and live stages, while the album's second single ''[[99 Luftballons]]'' peaked #1 in music charts worldwide including Australia, Japan, Austria, Canada, Ireland, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. Rakete says about Nena, "she could get anything across without explaining… That's an ability that is very rare. I do not know anyone of that caliber".<ref name=":2" />
[[Christiane F.]], writer of the autobiographical account [[Wir Kinder vom Bahnhof Zoo|Wir Kinder Vom Banhof Zoo]], gave a tape of Nena's song to DJ [[Rodney Bingenheimer]] who later aired the single on Californian rock radio WLIR, taking the song to #2 on US Billboard Hot 100. "Even if in German, people felt what ''99 Balloons'' meant and that was enough… It's like a good picture; it's unforgettable" Rakete later said about the hit single.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://tv.nrk.no/serie/hitlaatens-historie/mktf50000215/sesong-1/episode-2|title=NRK TV - Se "99 Luftballons"|website=NRK TV|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref>
In 1985 Rakete's management was chosen to produce [[:de:Band für Afrika|Band für Afrika]], the German counterpart of [[Band Aid (band)|Band Aid]]. The resulting single record was written by [[Herbert Grönemeyer]] and [[Wolfgang Niedecken|Wolfgang Niedeken]] and performed by 27 different German bands and musicians, including [[Alphaville (band)|Alphaville]], [[BAP (German band)|BAP]], [[Marius Müller-Westernhagen]], [[Nena]], [[Peter Maffay]], [[Spliff (band)|Spliff]] and [[Udo Lindenberg]]. Band für Afrika gathered over 150 million [[Deutsche Mark|Deutschmarks]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/1985/05/eine-platte-fuer-afrika|title=Eine Platte für Afrika|last=Rakete|first=Aufnahme: Jim|date=1985-01-25|newspaper=Die Zeit|issn=0044-2070|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref>
Meanwhile, Rakete had met the punk band [[Die Ärzte]] and put them in touch with CBS. Die Ärzte went on to be one of Germany's most successful bands. This was the final chapter of Fabrik Rakete, which was finally closed off in 1987.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artrenaline.com/v1/spezial/mentoren/jim-rakete.html|title=artrenaline,Designer René Fehrmann,Hamburg,Mentoren-Seite,Jim Rakete|last=Ridder|first=Jan|website=artrenaline.com|access-date=2016-05-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805091244/http://artrenaline.com/v1/spezial/mentoren/jim-rakete.html|archive-date=2016-08-05|url-status=dead}}</ref> Spliff went on producing music through a new venture. Rakete left the producing desk to fully focus on writing and photography full-time except in 1988-89, when he funded label [[ACT Music]] along with former president of [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Europe]] Siegfried Loch and [[Ideal (German band)|Ideal]]'s lead singer [[Annette Humpe]]. The label, which specializes in European Jazz, is active today.
== Photography == {{Quote|text=(Jim Rakete is) a photographer who over a period of thirty years has photographed other people with a unique kind of love, and who allows them to reveal themselves to him without holding anything back. You can’t hold anything back when faced with someone who doesn’t judge. You can feel his openness in these photos…. His book is a diary of feelings and relationships with people he has met. You can feel that he gives something to, rather than takes something away from those he photographs.|sign=[[Peter Lindbergh]]|source=[[Jim Rakete: Photographien 1977 - 1997]]}} [[File:TAKETE WENDERS LINDBERG.png|thumb|Jim Rakete, [[Peter Lindbergh]] and [[Wim Wenders]] in conversation in [[Düsseldorf]], June 2015]] Soon after the Fabrik's closure, Rakete began to almost exclusively shoot commercials and fashion spreads. In 1989, Rakete flew to Los Angeles to shoot a record video and album cover for [[Tangerine Dream]]'s [[Melrose (album)|''Melrose'']]. A year later, Rakete eventually rented a house in Hollywood, splitting his working year between the West Coast, Hamburg and Berlin, shooting video-clips, commercials, documentaries and fashion folders. During this period he befriended and photographed international artists, writers, film stars and directors.
With his first 1997 exhibit in Hamburg's Galerie Barlach, Rakete's work begins to regularly appear in international galleries.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Photographien 1970 - 1997|last=Lindbergh|first=Peter|publisher=Schirmer/Mosel|year=1997|isbn=3-88814-886-3|location=|pages=}}</ref>
In 2001 Rakete moves back to Berlin establishing his new working Studio in Kreuzberg. Between 2003 and 2004 he served as advisor for visual design of German political magazine ''[[Cicero (magazine)|Cicero]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cicero.de/berliner-republik/das-foto-des-jahres/36901|title=Das Foto des Jahres|website=Cicero Online|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref> Similar to [[The New Yorker]], ''Cicero'' allowed Rakete to combine his passion for people and politics, contributing with centerfold photo essays. Rakete's first reportage for Cicero was of former German Chancellor [[Gerhard Schröder]]'s trip to the White House to express his stance against the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]. The photographs were all black & white and primarily shot on a large plate Lintof camera. Rakete shot for Cicero for five more editions; personalities included [[Angela Merkel]], [[Willy Brandt]], [[Helmut Schmidt]], [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]] and [[Otto Schily]].[[File:Michael Ballhaus and Jim Rakete at Berlinale Hommage 2016.jpg|thumb|[[Michael Ballhaus]] and Jim Rakete at [[Berlin International Film Festival|Berlinale]] Hommage 2016]]In 2005, Rakete collaborated with designer [[:de:Ulf Meyer zu Kueingdorf|Ulf Meyer zu Küindorf]] and curator [[Mark Gisbourne]] on the catalogue ''Berlin Art Now'', published by [[Thames & Hudson|Thames and Hudson]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Berlin Art Now|last=Gisbourne|first=Marc|publisher=Thames and Hudson|year=2006|isbn=9780810992863|location=|pages=}}</ref> The English publication includes artists as [[John Bock]], [[Tacita Dean]], [[Jonathan Meese]], [[Monica Bonvicini]], [[:de:Bernhard Martin (Künstler)|Bernhard Martin]] and [[Yehudit Sasportas]].
In 2006, as chief consultant Rakete develops the art magazine ''Modernica'', a supplement of German newspaper [[Die Welt]] dealing with contemporary art with its main focus on photography, design and architecture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.art-magazin.de/kunst/7567-rtkl-jim-rakete-interview-man-weiss-immer-ob-ein-bild-knarrt|title=Jim Rakete - Interview: Man weiss immer, ob ein Bild knarrt|website=art|language=de-DE|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref>
In 2010, Rakete documented conductor [[Sir Simon Rattle]] and the [[Berlin Philharmonic|Berliner Philharmoniker]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://shop.berliner-philharmoniker.de/jim-rakete.html|title=Photo-book by Jim Rakete: The Berliner Philharmoniker up close|website=shop.berliner-philharmoniker.de|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref>
Rakete is currently continuing his activity as photographer, producer and writer. Over the years, his work has captured social and political events, and he has most notably portrayed personalities such as: [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Ray Charles]], [[David Bowie]], [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Mick Jagger]], [[David Byrne]], [[Kraftwerk]], [[Bono]], [[Deep Purple]], [[Joe Jackson (musician)|Joe Jackson]], [[Sean Connery]], [[Samuel Beckett]], [[Bruno Ganz]], [[Pier Paolo Pasolini]], [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]], [[Ute Lemper]], [[Martin Sheen]], [[Claude Chabrol]], [[Linda Evangelista]], [[Naomi Campbell]], [[Isabelle Huppert]], [[John Malkovich|John Malkovitch]], [[John Lurie]], [[Philip Johnson]], [[Anthony Perkins]], [[Sam Shepard]], [[Willem Dafoe]], [[Isabelle Huppert]], [[Julie Delpy]], [[Klaus Maria Brandauer|Klaus-Maria Brandauer]], [[Götz George]], [[Sebastian Koch]], [[Gérard Depardieu]], [[Christoph Waltz]], [[Emmanuelle Béart]], [[Liza Minnelli]], [[Sean Penn]], [[Isabella Rossellini]], [[Nina Hoss]], [[Otto Sander]], [[Natalie Portman]], [[Tangerine Dream]], [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Wim Wenders]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Photographien 1970 - 1997|last=Lindbergh|first=Peter|publisher=Schirmer/Mosel|year=1997|isbn=3888148863|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Selected Exhibitions == * 2016: ''Burgtheater | Innenleben'', Galerie Einstein Unter den Linden, Berlin * 2015: ''Burgtheater Innenleben'', Leica Galerie, Wien, Austria ''Burgtheater | Innenleben'', Leica Galerie Salzburg auf Schloss Arenberg, Salzburg, Austria ''FACE & FUTURE Gelecek ve Yüzleşme'', STIFTUNG MERCATOR, Essen * 2014: ''IKONEN - Ein Charityprojekt von Jim Rakete und Kilian Kerner'', Schneider Kreuznach, Bad Kreuznach ''<nowiki/>'Stand der Dinge - 100 Portraits für das Deutsche Filmmuseum'', FO.KU.S, Innsburck, Austria ''FACE & FUTURE Gelecek ve Yüzleşme'', ProjektZentrum Berlin der Stiftung Mercator, Berlin * 2013: ''VERTIGO'', MÜNZING CLAASSEN Galerie, Berlin ''IKONEN - Ein Charityprojekt von Jim Rakete und Kilian Kerner'', MÜNZING CLAASSEN Galerie, Berlin * 2012: ''STAND DER DINGE - 100 Porträts für das Deutsche Filmmuseum'', Willy Brandt Haus, Berlin ''Rockpoeten'', MÜNZING CLAASSEN Galerie, Berlin ''Wir & Ich (für Karuna e.V.)'', Museum Bensheim, Bensheim ''Porträtfotos der Berliner Philharmoniker'', Amthof-Galerie, Bad Camberg ''Jim Rakete - Werkschau'', Kunst- und Kulturzentrum der Städteregion Aachen, Monschau * 2011: ''STAND DER DINGE - 100 Porträts für das Filmmuseum Frankfurt'', Filmmuseum Frankfurt, Frankfurt * 2010: ''Straßenkinder für Karuna e.V.'', Leica Galerie, Solms ''Blicke gen Norden'', Patton Stiftung, Saarbrücken * 2009: ''1/8 sec. - Vertraute Fremde'', Ludwig Galerie Schloß Oberhausen, Oberhausen * 2008: ''Augen/Blick/Porträts'', Filmmuseum, Frankfurt ''1/8 sec. - Vertraute Fremde'', Camera Work, Berlin * 2006: ''Update'', M.J. Wewerka, Galerie, Berlin ''Streetfootball'', Künstlerhaus Bethanien, Berlin * 2002: ''Bleib So'', Haus der Stiftung Demokratie, Saarland * 1999: ''Jim Rakete - Photographien'', Suermondt-Ludwig-Museum, Aachen * 1997: ''Jim Rakete - Photographien'', Galerie Barlach, Hamburg
== References == {{reflist}}
*Jim Rakete (2015) Burgtheater. Innenleben (Burgtheatre Vienna. Inner Life), {{ISBN|9783000486944}} *Jim Rakete (2010) Die Berliner Philharmoniker Stiftung Berliner Philharmoniker, {{ISBN|3000324089}} *Jim Rakete (2011) ''Stand der Dinge: 100 Porträts für das Deutsche Filmmuseum.'' Schirmer/Mosel, München, {{ISBN|978-3-8296-0533-5}} *Jim Rakete (2008) - 1/8 sec. Vertraute Fremde: Familiar Strangers, Schirmer/Mosel 2008, {{ISBN|3829602960}} *Ulf Meyer zu Küingdorf, Jim Rakete, Mark Gisbourne (2006) Kunststation Berlin, Knesebeck, {{ISBN|3896603647}} *Marc Gisbourne (2006) Berlin Art Now, Abrams, {{ISBN|9780810992863}} *Jim Rakete and Jeannot Simmen (2006) Totalschaden, B&S Siebenhaar, {{ISBN|3379008389}} *Moon Suk (2006) Mond und Sterne: ''22 poetische Porträts'', Wunderlich, {{ISBN|3805208103}} *Klaus Hoffman and Jim Rakete (2002) Klaus Hoffmann Sänger: Sämtliche Lieder, Ullstein, {{ISBN|3898340511}} *Nina Hagen and Marcel Feige (2002) Nina Hagen. That's why the lady is a punk, Schwarzkopf + Schwarzkopf, {{ISBN|3896024132}} *Jim Rakete (2000) Workbook - Heidelberger Druckmaschinen AG, Heidelberg 2000 (People in the Graphic Arts Industry), ASIN: B00A37VNO2 *Jim Rakete, Rolf Hosfeld, Rainer Wörtmann (1999) Friedrichstadtpalast Berlin, Metz ''Europas größtes Revue-Theater.'' Metz, Hamburg, {{ISBN|3-9805563-3-6}} *Jim Rakete, Peter Lindbergh (1997) Photographien 1970 - 1997, Schirmer/Mosel, {{ISBN|3-88814-886-3}} *Rene Lezard (Hrsg.) (1986) Jim Rakete. The Complete Key West Session. Lezard, Schwarzach 1986 ASIN: B002BZ9JAO

Jim Rakete: promo for the live recording of "The Spliff Radio Show"] at the "Berliner [[Rocknacht]]" on August 15, 1981 * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FZTGvFdxkE4 A video portrait of Nena by Jim Rakete] , 1983 * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BxlSIIdb1Xs Nena on Jim Rakete] , 1987 *[https://vimeo.com/132687621 Peter Lindbergh / Jim Rakete / Wim Wenders in conversation] at Museum Kunstpalast in Düsseldorf in June 2015 (in German) *[https://vimeo.com/121661816 Vienna Leica Gallery: Jim Rakete's portraits of the Burgtheater's ensemble] , 2015 {{authority control}}
